newsitem.title: UK: "Green" tax reforms could create UK jobs-study.
newsitem.headline: "Green" tax reforms could create UK jobs-study.

text.p: Higher taxes on pollution and waste in Britain could raise over 20 billion stg a year in revenue and create over half a million new jobs, the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR) said.

The left-of-centre think-tank proposed a package of measures including a commercial and industrial energy tax, higher road fuel duties and waste disposal taxes, a quarrying tax, an office parking tax and an end to company car perks.

Authors Stephen Tindale and Gerald Holtham said environmental taxes were an effective means of securing environmental goals and the extra revenue could also be used to reduce national insurance, value-added tax and business rates.
"Environmental taxes can be good for the economy, encouraging companies to use resources more efficiently and stimulating innovation and development of new products and processes," the IPPR said.
Progressive tax reforms could protect low-income families without damaging the competitiveness of British industry, it said.

If all the revenue was used to reduce national insurance contributions, the IPPR model, which was simulated by Cambridge Econometrics, suggested employment in both manufacturing and services would increase.
"Over 700,000 new jobs would be created by 2005," the IPPR said.
